body: The views are not commanding, unless you count the one of the exhaust stations for the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. Yet champions of the Brooklyn Motor Inn say it is a promising idea for a new hotel in New York for an unlikely reason: it's in Red Hook. ''We've got everything you need right here,'' said Sal Faraone, manager of the Motor Inn, speaking
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK; In Area Where Capone Roamed, Inn Burnishes a Changing Image

body: THE revised zoning adopted for Park Slope last April affects almost all the blocks from Warren Street south to 15th Street and from Third Avenue to Prospect Park, excluding only a manufacturing zone nearer the Gowanus Canal. It gives Brooklyn its largest contextual zoning district, comparable to others adopted in Manhattan over the years. Its basic
title: How the Zoning Works

body: NEW YORK is an organic creature, capable of lifting your soul skyward one day, then grinding it slowly to powder the next. But who knew that the city manipulated inanimate objects as whimsically as people? I'm talking about my box of old clothes. I recently moved to the south end of Carroll Gardens, a nether region of welding shops and warehouses.
title: URBAN STUDIES/SHEDDING; Another Curbside Attraction

body: The finale of a powerful two-day storm roared across the New York metropolitan area and played out over the Northeast yesterday, burying parts of the region in more than a foot of snow that set a record, slowed travel, challenged Christmas shoppers and transformed the landscape into vistas as uncluttered as early maps of America. The marathon
title: A PREWINTER SNOW: THE OVERVIEW; 2ND DAY OF SNOW PUMMELS REGION, SETTING RECORDS

body: To the Editor: My uncle too is a hoarder. Our family has long wondered whether he will be found under a pile of New Yorker magazines, uncashed checks, unopened presents, prisms (his most prized possessions) and old postcards and fliers. The last time there was room for me to walk through his house in Brooklyn, seven years ago, I was fascinated by
title: Pack Rats In Our Midst

body: The new fall season on television bristles with radical change. The best-paid stars of the ABC series ''The Practice'' were all fired. Aaron Sorkin left ''The West Wing'' on NBC, leaving his White House in the hands of new writers determined to ramp up the sex and violence. And Crosswalks, New York City's cable television station, is now called NYC
title: TELEVISION REVIEW; Civics Splashed With Celebrities, Fashion and a Techno Beat

body: ''FLAMBOYAN.'' ''OCK.'' ''HARLOW.'' The letters are brushed in white paint on a red brick wall in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, facing the playground of Public School 38. They are older than any student at the school; they have been there longer than any of the teachers. They are etchings from another era, fashioned by a hand that long ago grew too big to
title: Remains Of the Day

body: The seasoned motorist or indefatigable road-tripper, even the operator of a taximeter cabriolet, must at some point face that dark, despairing moment of hapless reckoning, staring dumbfounded at some of New York City's street signs. The moment often comes when the time is wrong for contemplation, when the driver is late and harried and cursing at
title: Following New York Signs Is Long Way to Nowhere

author: A. O. Scott is a film critic for The Times.
body: THE FORTRESS OF SOLITUDE By Jonathan Lethem. 511 pp. New York: Doubleday. $26. The neighborhood now known as Boerum Hill is a slice of Brooklyn that extends along a few quiet, tree-lined streets layered between the antique stores and Middle Eastern groceries of Atlantic Avenue and the viscid green torpor of the Gowanus Canal. The area, shadowed by
title: When Dylan Met Mingus

body: When Jonathan Lethem was growing up on Dean Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, one of the few white faces in a black and Hispanic sea, he was constantly being grabbed and frisked for his pocket change or bus pass by the neighborhood kids, he recalled the other day. It was the 1970's, before great waves of middle-class homesteaders cascaded through
title: Untangling the Knots Of a Brooklyn Boyhood

body: THE FORTRESS OF SOLITUDE By Jonathan Lethem 511 pages. Doubleday. $26. Jonathan Lethem's dazzling but fundamentally flawed new novel, ''The Fortress of Solitude,'' is at once wildly ambitious and quietly intimate. It aspires to the social range and reach of John Updike's Rabbit novels and Michael Chabon's 2000 novel, ''The Amazing Adventures of
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; White Kid, In a Black World

body: Brooklyn residents who want to sink the 3.5-mile elevated stretch of the Gowanus Expressway underground got a chill last month when they learned that the state's Department of Transportation had designated $344 million to shore up the existing structure. The money will go toward resurfacingthe road, which state officials said isnecessary for
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTH BROOKLYN; The State Patches Up a Road That Residents Want to Ditch

body: They did not even see the pale fleck of the airplane streak across the corner of the video camera's field of view at 8:46 a.m. But the camera, pointed at the twin towers from the passenger seat of an S.U.V. in Brooklyn near the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, kept rolling when the plane disappeared for an instant and then a silent, billowing cloud of
title: TWO YEARS LATER: IMAGES; A Rare View Of Sept. 11, Overlooked

body: ON a quiet side street in the East Village lies the New York City Marble Cemetery, the second nonsectarian cemetery built in Manhattan. Created in 1832 by several enterprising businessmen as a profit-making venture, the cemetery provides a social hub and respite for its neighbors that surpass its original intent. Residents and curious passers-by
title: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; A Cemetery for the Living

body: Even in these days of computer games, conditioned air and liability lawsuits, the people of New York still go to the roof. They charge through security doors and climb up fire escapes, and nervous landlords or busybody building superintendents are no match. They go seeking cool relief, a little conversation, the spectacular belvedere from what
title: On the Roof, Another New York, Above It All

body: New Yorkers with cars have access to suburban nurseries that might stock something more than ho-hum impatiens and curbside petunias. Now the Gowanus Nursery, which has opened in a part of Brooklyn that could be called Carroll Gardens Adjacent, is drawing even suburbanites for its species lilies and bold variegated aralia with six-foot leaves.
title: CURRENTS: NURSERIES; Now, Lilies and Sedums Grow in Brooklyn

body: Cruising the Gowanus Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment; (718) 788-8500, ext. 208. The center will offer a cruise along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn from 9 a.m. to noon on Sunday, to look at changes in the waterway and at the history and industrial architecture in the surrounding neighborhood. The cruise departs from Pier 62 at Chelsea
title: CALENDAR

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Made in the Bronx Q. I recently came across a passing reference to the dome of the United States Capitol that said it had been created in the Bronx and then shipped to Washington. Can you fill in some details? A. Not only was one of the most visible icons of American democracy built in the Bronx, the company that was awarded the contract opened a
title: F.Y.I.

body: Motorists leaving Brooklyn will soon encounter signs encouraging them to stay, Borough President Marty Markowitz said yesterday. ''Leaving Brooklyn, Fugheddaboudit.'' the signs read. Mr. Markowitz explained, ''Once you enter Brooklyn, there's no good reason why you should ever leave.'' Officials plan to place the signs at exit points on the Gowanus
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: New Signs Ask, 'So Why Leave?'

body: The police yesterday identified the young woman whose body was found burned in a Brooklyn parking lot as a 19-year-old from the Bronx who had been reported missing days earlier. The police also released photographs of the woman, Taisha Camacho. The police are trying to determine her whereabouts between May 4, when she was reported missing, and May
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Corpse Is Identified

body: She recently had a pedicure. Her teeth were pristine. She had not taken drugs and had no criminal record. Those facts, along with a haunting sterling silver pendant depicting a blazing sun, are among the few clues the police have to solve the mysterious killing of a young woman. Her nearly naked body was set ablaze on May 7 outside an auto repair
title: Burned Body In Brooklyn Still a Puzzle To the Police

body: Pretty soon, a 1-year-old harp seal that became the talk of Red Hook is expected to paddle onto Long Island Sound, leaving behind its celebrity in Brooklyn for a life of anonymity in open waters. For years, runners and fishermen have reported glimpsing just such a seal sliding through the Gowanus Canal and its nearby bay. Many scoffed at the
title: A Brooklyn Seal's Trick: Surviving the Gowanus

body: Theater ''FAIRY TALES OF THE ABSURD,'' with works by Eugène Ionesco and Edward Einhorn, by the Untitled Theater Company No. 61 at Theater 80, 80 St. Marks Place, East Village. body: A Fable That Soars An adult looking at a child's drawing rarely sees what the young artist intends. The image that looks like a hat to a grown-up may be, in the child's words, ''a boa constrictor having swallowed an elephant.'' It is this exact misunderstanding that leads the narrator of ''The Little Prince'' to give up drawing -- that is, until,
title: FAMILY FARE

body: It all started out as a bit of a lark. To generate a little buzz about the 20th anniversary celebration of the Marco Polo Ristorante in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, the owner, Joe Chirico, and a public relations consultant thought they would try to find a relative of the great traveler himself who might be persuaded to come. They did not have great
title: Finding China, on a Brooklyn Table; A Kinsman of Marco Polo Eats Italian in Carroll Gardens

body: It was perhaps surprising when Rudolph W. Giuliani and his betrothed, Judith Nathan, chose Gracie Mansion over, say, the St. Regis for the site of their wedding. And odd that they tapped Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, an avowed disbeliever in marriage, to officiate. True, Mr. Bloomberg has his oratorical charms. And he was diplomatic enough to
title: 6 Weddings and a Disclaimer: They're All in Caterers' Dreams; What Might Have Been for Giuliani and His Bride

body: HIGHLIGHTS DYLAN TALKS TO SCORSESE -- Bob Dylan is to be interviewed by Martin Scorsese for a documentary that will examine the singer's early career and the cultural and political impact of his music. The BBC, which will finance the production in part, said yesterday that the film would have its premiere on its network and in the United States on
title: ARTS BRIEFING

body: Ah, the Gowanus, that fetid Brooklyn canal synonymous with contamination and death. Sewage, industrial waste -- perhaps even human remains -- still molder at its murky bottom. On occasion, its famously noxious, sulfurous aroma wafts over its banks. But now, as if to collect that batty neighbor living in a clutter of cats and old string, the men
title: What Rots Beneath; Investigating Exactly What Fouls the Gowanus Canal

body: INTERNATIONAL A2-9 Jerusalem Suicide Attacks Threaten Peace Effort Palestinian suicide attacks killed nine bystanders in Jerusalem, prompting Prime Minister Ariel Sharon to postpone a trip to see President Bush, repudiate the new international peace plan, and decide that Israel will shun foreign representatives who meet with Yasir Arafat. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: Ferry service between Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan, one of the small changes wrought by the upheaval of Sept. 11, is slated to end next Wednesday, much to the consternation of some commuters and elected officials. The free service, which shuttles riders from the Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park to Pier 11 in Lower Manhattan, was started just
title: Free Brooklyn-Manhattan Ferry to End Soon

body: By the moment the war started, the old- timers -- the ones who may have lain in the trenches in one of the world wars -- had long since gone. At the Michael A. Rawley Jr. American Legion Post near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, the bar had only a few patrons and was quiet -- save the news of the conflict being broadcast on two televisions. Bob King
title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: REACTION -- THE VETERANS; Legion Post Is Quiet

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement. body: The intricate geography of income difference in New York City is something Chastity Davis absorbed early, growing up in the 1980's in a tenement apartment in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, on a block of mostly brick row houses flanked by public housing projects at either end. At the neighborhood elementary school, Ms. Davis's friends were from the
title: Here, Poverty And Privilege Are Neighbors; Income Gaps Are a Source Of Resentment and Guilt

body: TIMING is everything in comedy, and there are moments when the timing in ''Romeo and Bernadette,'' a new musical at the Paper Mill, is hilariously perfect. The timing of the overall show, however, is not quite as good; this lighthearted merging of Shakespeare and ''The Sopranos'' feels as if it has arrived a few years too late. Positing that the
title: THEATER REVIEW; It's Love, in Verona by the Gowanus

body: It was probably the very day furniture was invented that seating order became a measure of social status. Today it's about being to the left or right of the host, at the head table, in the front row. In Tudor England it wasn't about where but on what. Only the man of the house or important guests got the chairs. And beautiful chairs they were,
title: The Seats of Power (The Beds, Too)

body: I don't remember exactly when I realized that my neighborhood had arrived, but I think it was sometime between the opening of the Japanese tapas bar and the European-style pressed sandwich cafe, a few doors down. In Park Slope, Brooklyn, Fifth Avenue has long been the poorer, grittier cousin to Seventh Avenue, the area's main dining and shopping
title: MY BROOKLYN; Racing Upscale At Full Throttle

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Many Cold, Few Frozen Q. I've noticed the ice on the Hudson and East Rivers during this cold wave, and I'm wondering if the rivers have ever frozen. A. While it is not uncommon for Hudson River to freeze upstate, it rarely happens in the city; once, to be exact. In 1821, amid one of the coldest winters of the century, New Yorkers awoke on Jan. 25
title: F.Y.I.
